trial_identification.studytitle: Does Morosil (red orange) extract reduce the risk factors of metabolic syndrome?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of Morosil extract in combination with nutritional intervention on the risk factors of metabolic syndrome

interventions.interventions: Morosil extract capsule 250mg oral administration, twice per day before meals for three months. Bioactive substances present in this red orange juice extract include: Anthocyanins 0.8 0.9%, Flavonoids 2 2.2%, Hydroxycinnamic acid 0.8 1.0%, and Ascorbic acid 4.3 4.5%. Nutritional intervention involving the dietary recommendation on the individual bases will be provided to both groups. Participants will receive the recommendations once a week in the teaching clinic of Victoria University, St Albans campus.
interventions.comparator: Placebo capsule containing maltodextrin, 250mg oral administration, twice per day before meals for three months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: weight loss - this will be assessed through physical measurement of body weight.
triglyceride reduction - blood analysis will be conducted.
reduction in waist circumference - this will be assessed through physical measurement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: change in basal metobolic rate (BMR) - this will be assessed using metabolic cart.
change in body composition examination using DEXA.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Males and females aged 30-60 years with a BMI greater than 25 or a waist circumference > 94cm for males and >80cm for females.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Liver, kidney and heart disease, pregnancy, type 1 and type 2 diabetes with insulin medication, cigarette smoking and the use of any medication for weight loss.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: McKechnie Street St Albans, PO BOX 14428 Melbourne, Victoria 8001

fundingsource.fundingaddress: McKechnie Street St Albans, PO BOX 14428 Melbourne, Victoria 8001

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A 3-month intervention using encapsulated red orange (Citrus sinensis) juice extract in combination with nutritional intervention to investigate whether or not red orange juice extract decreases the risk factors of metabolic syndrome

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Victoira University Human Research Ethics Committee
